dialogues.text: Karen.  They're not up here.  Keep your eyes open. Karen looks off towards the street entrance, then back at elevator where the man is still waiting, leaning on his c The elevator door opens to reveal Buddy and Foley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Going up? Buddy and Foley don't answer.  The old man starts to get feeling with his cane, taking forever. Karen and Foley are staring at each other.  He doesn't mo Not until the elevator door begins to close. Buddy sees Karen, helps the old man aboard as... Karen picks up her radio, is about to speak into it when. Foley raises his hand.  And waves as the door closes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the elevator resumes going down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, I wanted to go up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's just hope there's no one in the garage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looked right at me.  She didn't yell or get excited.  She didn't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they get in and Buddy starts the car...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They know where I live, I guess they know what I drive, so maybe we should pick up another car on the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She just sat there, looking right at me. Buddy gives him a look, shakes his head and then burns ru out of the garage as we...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Staring straight ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen.  Report.  You see anything? Karen?  You there?  Karen...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Marshall walks Karen to the gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waved to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't swear to it, but I'm pretty sure he did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wave back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't have time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I imagine you would've though. She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buddy's sister Regina Mary Bragg got two calls from Buddy up in Detroit this morning, called Burdon.  She's also the one gave Burdon Buddy's address.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what I want to know is why Buddy still calls his sister every week even after she turned him in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't seem to hold a grudge. (then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I want to know is why, they got such a big score up north, did Foley hang around Miami for so long? (looks at her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any thoughts on that one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None I'd like to share. She gives him a kiss...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll call soon as I get in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snow.  Everywhere.  A black Lincoln Town Car creeps throu neighbourhood full of big, beautiful snow-covered homes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't just manage fighters, or deal product any more...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glenn -- sunglasses -- sits in the back with Maurice, aka wearing a purple bandanna and his own dark sunglasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've diversified since the last time you saw me.  I've vertically integrated and now I'm into home invasions and the occasional grand larceny. Glenn just nods, stares out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: White Boy Bob's my all-around man, my bodyguard when I feel I need one, and my driver. Maurice indicates WHITE BOY BOB, a fucking huge, depraved looking white guy now squeezed in behind the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch the road, boy. (then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like this Town Car.  We can cruise the man's neighbourhood without getting the police or private security people on our ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, right, they see Bigfoot driving around a black guy wearing shades and a lavender fucking bandanna, no, they won't think anything of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's lilac, man, the color, and the style's made known by Deion and other defensive backs in the pros.  I could be one of them living out here with doctors of my race and basketball players.  Okay, here comes Mr. Ripley's house up on the left.  Yeah.  The brick wall.  There's his drive, right there. The car creeps past a huge Tudor-style country house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure Foley and his pal aren't coming up here, do this themself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they're not busted now, they're gonna be. (then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's wide open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People on the street with vacant expressions watch as the Town Car moves past the broken-down homes, cars on blocks snow-covered trash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you still haven't said, how you wanna do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll show you, soon as I get one more guy I'm gonna need, Moselle's brother, Kenneth.  Along with White Boy there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? The car pulls to the kerb and KENNETH -- a wiry black man bright yellow T-shirt and red baseball cap backward, alwa seems to be high on some chemical or another - gets in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get everything? Kenneth tosses a gym bag into the back seat.  Glenn stare it.  Something about the bag makes him uneasy.  Maybe it' HACKSAW that sticks partially out of the opening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool.  Kenneth, this is the man I told you about, Glenn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The one gonna help us rip off the rich guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help you... White Boy Bob pulls out again. Glenn looks at the two ps in front, then turns to Maurice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. I'm letting you in on this, not all your friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just ask me how we gonna do it. That's what I'm here for, tell you how.  We the experts. Glenn can't believe this is happening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thing I'm worried about is you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  If you can step up and actually do it.  Understand?  'Stead of just talking the talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I do what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walk in a house with me, do this cross- dressin' nigga named Eddie Solomon I used to sell to been dealin' on his own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What-- when?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right now, son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have to prove shit to you. The Ripley job is my job. You're either in or you're not. You wanna pop some crack dealer pissed you off, that's your problem, not mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Glenn, I know you cool, but you don't have to give me no tone of voice, okay?  You don't like what I'm saying, you can get out anywhere along here you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're forgetting, this is my car.  I drove it up here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, shit, come on. I say I want this car, man, it's mine. You go get yourself another one. I say I'm in on Ripley? I'm in, with or without your ass. I say I want you to come along on another job, see if you for real or not, guess what you gonna do? Glenn looks at Maurice, now ice-cold behind the shades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're here. Glenn looks out the window as they pull up in front of a looking two-story house.  Maurice opens the gym bag, pass hack saw and a HAND AXE up to White Boy Bob, a SAWED-OFF to Kenneth, and takes out a big .45 for himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go see Eddie. Glenn hesitates, then slowly gets out of the car as we he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must take balls, do what you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Foley walks with Ripley across the yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me something.  What's it like, walk in a bank with a gun, stick it up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  I never used a gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd be surprised what all you can get, you ask for it the right way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the reason, Jack, I don't keep all my money in banks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No?  Where do you keep it, Dick? (Ripley smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm talking about all those uncut diamonds you told Glenn about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what you're talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the one with balls, Dick, say something like that to someone like Glenn.  Or maybe you just forgot where you were for a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but who's gonna believe Glenn? I mean, do you believe Glenn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plus, even it was true, he'd still have to figure out where I keep 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't have to figure out shit.  You told him you keep 'em at your house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs, big smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a big house. Ripley sits down on one of the picnic tables, looks aroun yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me something, Jack, how much longer you in here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-two months, three days, two hours.  Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just thinking that I could use a guy like you, someone knows how to ask for things the right way.  I'm talkin' about when you're outta here.  I mean, you can't rob banks for ever. Foley looks at Ripley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a little late for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Jack?  Bullshit.  I didn't make my first million until I was forty- two.  Forty-two.  You really want to change, it's never too late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  I'm not exactly the nine-to-five type.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is? But then you gotta look at a job as more than just work. You gotta look at it as peace of mind. As security, you know what I mean? I got offices in Detroit, Miami, Boston, take your pick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My ex-wife's in Miami.  It's nice down there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No need to decide now.  Be like the fish.  Let whatever happens happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fish?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, fish live in the present.  They don't dwell on yesterday and they don't worry about tomorrow.  Even when a big fish attacks a little fish, there's no neurosis involved.  No guilt afterward. No whining on some fish-shrink's couch. They just do it.  They accept.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't say that I've paid that much attention to 'em before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fish saved my life.  Two years ago, I found out I had high blood pressure.  So my doctor, he tells me to go get an aquarium, look at the fish every time I felt myself stressing out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the guy sent you a bill for this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It works.  You should try it sometime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next time I walk into a bank. Ripley shakes his head, then gets up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think about my offer, Jack. Foley watches him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Jack...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: As he turns to us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: PULL BACK TO REVEAL
dialogues.text: Across the street from the KRONK RECREATION CENTER -- a r brick building in a bleak, depressing neighbourhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see this one... Buddy reads from a newspaper while Foley watches the gym.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Fight over tuna casserole may have spurred slaying."  Seems this woman's live-in boyfriend, seventy years old, complained about her tuna noodle casserole and she shot him in the face with a twelve-gauge.  Police found noodles in the woman's hair and think the guy dumped the casserole dish on her before she shot him.  They'd been together ten years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love is funny. Buddy looks at him.  Notices something over Foley's shoul

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey-- And now Foley turns and looks over as the black Town Car pulls into the Kronk parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenneth and White Boy Bob nod along to some rap tape in t front seat.  Glenn sits in the back, looking pale, huggin himself, shaking.  Maurice looks out the window...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was a time you see a gold Mercedes over in the parking lot has a license plate on it say HITMAN?  You know Tommy Hearns is inside.  Seeing the car would get our juices flowing. Maurice looks at Glenn now and grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You already got your juices flowing, huh?  Pissed your pants back there at Eddie's house, didn't you? Glenn just looks at Maurice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was some shit, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicates Kenneth)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why'd he have to do that to that girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Kenneth, why you have to do that to that poor girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do what? Glenn says nothing, just looks at Kenneth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just wait till we get inside Ripley's house. And he and Whiteboy start laughing as they get out of the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right with you, I'll just hang in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  You gonna stay close to me from now on.  So you don't disappear on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would I do that? Maurice looks at him, starts laughing.  White Boy Bob and join in.  Maurice leans over... Glenn flinches as Maurice Glenn's jacket so that we can see the BLOOD splattered on shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was worse than you imagined, wasn't it? (then, smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby, you with the bad boys now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they watch Glenn and Snoopy and White Boy Bob get out car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatta you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think Glenn opened his big mouth and now we got us another partner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glenn sits on a bench near the rear wall, facing the ring Kenneth grabs a magazine, walks into the john.  A shirtle White Boy Bob lifts weights while Maurice moves around th calling to the boxers inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stick and jab!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Studs, how you doing? He looks up, sees Buddy and Foley coming this way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, what're you guys doing here? They sit down on either side of him, close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weren't you expecting us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That broad you picked up -- did you know she was a US Marshal, for Christ sake? Now he turns to Buddy as Buddy stands up, takes off his o and sits down again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She knew me from some bullshit dope bust. She drove me to court. Twice. You know what she said, we're in the car on the turnpike? "I never forget anybody I've cuffed and shackled."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?  She said that to you? Glenn turns to see Foley with a mild expression on his fa almost smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to your shades?  Someone finally step on 'em?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (touches his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... Foley notices the blood on Glenn's shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whose blood you got all over you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These guys, man, they're crazy. (looks off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. Foley follows his gaze, sees Maurice coming this way, Whi Bob beside him, carrying his shirts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that Snoopy?  In the purple doo rag?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he do now, tell fortunes? Maurice stands at the edge of the ring apron, looks from to Buddy and back again, pretty serious about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a problem here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack Foley, famous bank robber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snoopy Miller, famous fight thrower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seems to me I been reading about you in the newspaper.  Busted out of some joint in Florida, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Low class of people there, Snoop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You call him that again I'll put your head through the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  You mean Snoop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody calls me Snoop no more or Snoopy, is what White Boy's trying to say. He's a little crude, you understand. No, I left that Snoopy shit behind me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you call this bozo White Boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: White Boy Bob. (baiting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: White Boy used to be a fighter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he do now outside of shoot his mouth off? White Boy Bob stares down Buddy who couldn't give a shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like being back in the yard, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like it.  Nobody backing down. You back down, you pussy.  Tell me what you and Buddy doing up here in the cold?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glenn didn't tell you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you guys were busted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?  Just because you left us standing on the side of the road? Foley looks at Glenn.  Glenn shrugs, laughs nervously.  F smiles, laughs with him, maybe a little too hard.  Now Ma starts laughing.  Buddy, too.  White Boy's lost, looking one guy to the next as Foley gets up, faces Maurice, his going away as he says...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Snoop, I don't know what Glenn promised you or what you think you're gonna get, but the deal is me and Buddy get half of whatever we take from Ripley, understand?  How you and Glenn cut up the rest is up to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go outside and talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter with right here? It's nice and warm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warm?  Man, it's ninety-five degrees in here, sometimes a hundred -- the way Emanuel always kep' it so his boys'd sweat, get lean and mean like Tommy Hearns.  No, I ain't talking any business in here.  To me this is holy ground, man.  You understand?  I got to be someplace anyway.  Y'all want to talk, come to the fights tomorrow night, we'll sit down and look at it good. The State Theater. Foley nods then looks at Glenn as Buddy gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll see you tomorrow then. Maurice then watches as they walk out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: White Boy, how much is the reward on the man again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten gees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. (then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You recall, did it say dead or alive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same decrepit two-storey place Maurice et al hit earl Now it's a CRIME SCENE.  A SMALL CROWD of neighbourhood g stand just behind the yellow tape.  A HUGE SPOTLIGHT ligh the front yard. Karen pulls up in her rental car, gets out and badges the freezing COP at the tape, working crowd control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm looking for Ray Cruz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's inside. (pissed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With everybody else. Karen ducks under the tape and starts up the walk.  She p to watch as two CORONER'S ASSISTANTS cover with a sheet a BLACK WOMAN who lies just below a broken upstairs window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell.  Karen has to step over a body minus a face that li the doorway.  Straight ahead on the stairs is another bod MAN ON HIS BACK, head down the stairs, shotgun blast to t chest.  He wears a dress, now bunched up around his waist Congealed blood runs down the stairs.  COPS and CRIME SCE TECHS are everywhere.  Karen looks at the guy on the stai

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Called themselves the Youngboys. Karen looks over as RAYMOND CRUZ, a stocky, genial-lookin detective comes out of the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ironic, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you, Raymond?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freezing.  But I'm getting warmer. He kisses her on the cheek.  She indicates the body by th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite a mess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  And I thought everyone liked Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dude in the dress is Eddie Solomon, used to buy scag off a corner till he kicked it and found his happiness with crack and then started dealing himself. Word on the street was he was saving up for an operation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it with crack and transsexuals?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Eddie was a real character.  Had these girls cooked the rocks he called the Rockettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  I saw one of 'em outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yonelle.  Looks like someone raped her, shot her, then threw her out the window. (shakes his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuckin' animals. This shuts them both up.  Cruz indicates the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get some air. She starts to follow him out, pauses as she sees somethin the ground...

dialogues.speaker: A BROKEN PAIR OF SUNGLASSES
dialogues.text: Wrap-around... a lot like the ones she remembers Glenn we Karen stares at them a moment, then walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Cruz and Karen walk to his car, STROBES FLASH as press photographers struggle to shoot the crime scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Other than we had so much fun the last time we worked together.  You gonna tell me why you're comin' to me instead of the FBI?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I report to the FBI, first thing they're gonna do is ask me to go get some coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I'm not in homicide any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I didn't know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm crimes against persons and property now, also sex crimes and child abuse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Detroit, you must be pretty busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, and, as you can see, home invasions are big, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Raymond, a year ago, DEA had this guy Glenn Michaels on possession with intent but couldn't make it stick. In his statement, Glenn said he went up to Detroit to visit a friend and look into job opportunities -- if you can believe that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was the friend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy named Maurice Miller, also known as Snoopy, a former prizefighter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ, I know Snoopy Miller.  He's a fuckin' wackjob thinks he's Sugar Ray Leonard.  Hangs out with a couple other Grade-A nutcases over on the West side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll need a last known address.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's fine, but I don't want you to talk to Miller alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Raymond, I'm a federal officer, I'm armed. He turns and looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, you are.  I'll call you tomorrow with the address. As he gets into his car, we then:

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: The crime scene from the night before.  A shot of Karen a Cruz as they exit the house.  A headline reads "TRIPLE MU blah-blah-blah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have the paper?

dialogues.speaker: REVEAL
dialogues.text: Foley, wearing a suit now, no shoes, no tie, looks at the newspaper photograph of Karen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a terrific shot of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buddy looking at the same shot...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside of that. INTERCUTTING FOLEY & BUDDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't say what she's doing up here, but I don't think it has anything to do with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She came up here on her vacation, 'cause she likes shitty weather. Foley reaches in one of the bags from the Jewish Recyclin and pulls out a tie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think she's after Glenn.  The girl still with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't stay the night, Jack, 'less you pay for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tell your sister about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just hung up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long you talk to her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long were you with the girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forty-five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't tell your sister about Ripley, did you?  'Cause I don't wanna go through that again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget about my sister.  If Karen Sisco's tailing Glenn, we're fucked. Tomorrow night at the fights we all get picked up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's drive by where we're meeting and have a look.  Maybe take a look at Ripley's place while we're at it. Foley hangs up.  He faces the mirror, starts to tie his t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess next time I see you, you'll be wearing a suit and tie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Foley leans in the doorway watching as Ripley, dressed in jogging suit, and under the watchful eye of A GUARD, gath his belongings.  He's going home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still haven't made up my mind yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's to think about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You goin' right back to work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First, I'm goin' to Israel for a year, study the Talmud, work on a Kibbutz... then come back, maybe take some tennis lessons. He tears a picture off the wall...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here... (hands it to Foley)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something to remember me by. Foley stares at the photograph of sea life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not the real thing, but it's still nice to look at. Foley looks at Ripley, who extends his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you on the outside, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Foley finishes tying his tie, stares into the mirror, tak the overall effect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi!  I just broke outta jail! His smile fades, he then sits down heavily on the bed, lo the picture of Karen another moment, then sets the paper grabs the Yellow Pages, flips to HOTELS, and dials the ph

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Atheneum Hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen Sisco, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause, then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, but there's no one by that name registered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. He dials the next number...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best Western...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red brick, showing its age.  Karen rings the doorbell and waits with her hands shoved into the pockets of her dark, coat.  The door opens to reveal Moselle in her green silk holding her arms close against the cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moselle Miller?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm looking for Maurice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You find him, tell him the dog got run over and I'm out of grocery money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moselle.  Who you talking to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lady looking for Maurice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's she want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hasn't said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not Maurice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Kenneth, my brother.  He's talking on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask what she want with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ask her. Maurice's business is none of my business. Sounding tired or bored. She turns from the door and wal into the living room. Karen steps inside, pushes the doo closed and steps into the foyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do I know? Karen peers into a study, a small room with empty bookcas sees Kenneth in his backward red baseball cap as he talks the phone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The State, huh.  Who's fighting? Karen walks into the living room, where Moselle sits on t lighting a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like to sit down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. Karen takes a chair and looks around the room: dismal, gr daylight in the windows, dark wood and white stucco, the fireplace full of trash, plastic cups, wrappers, a pizza

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm looking for a friend of mine I think Maurice knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You not with probation, one of those?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You a lawyer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm not.  Maybe you know him. Glenn Michaels? Moselle draws on her cigarette, blows out a stream of smo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glenn?  No, I don't know any Glenn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said he stayed here last November.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here?  In this house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said he stayed with Maurice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he ain't even here that much. I like to know where he goes, but at the same time I don't want to know, you understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your dog was killed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got run over by a car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you call it? Moselle looks at the couch, where a MANGLED FRISBEE sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was a she, name Tuffy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods, then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you think I might find Maurice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know -- the gym, the fights. I know he don't miss the fights. Having some tomorrow night at the State Theater. He use to take me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The State Theater?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you want with Maurice? Karen turns, sees Kenneth standing in the arched entrance the foyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looking for a man name of Glenn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I ask you?  Go on out of here.  Do something with yourself. He waits until Moselle gets up, not saying a word, walks from them through the dining room.  Karen watches him com her now in kind of an easy strut.  She indicates the scar his eye...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a fighter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was... He moves his head in what might be a feint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Till I got my retina detached two time. He's standing so close to her, Karen has to look up at hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you fight, middleweight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Light to super-middleweight, as my body developed.  You go about what, bantam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flyweight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know your divisions.  You like the fights?  Like the rough stuff?  Yeah, I bet you do. (moves closer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like to get down and tussle a little bit?  Like me and Tuffy, before she got run over, we use to get down on the floor and tussle.  I say to her, "You a good dog, Tuffy, here's a treat for you."  And I give Tuffy what every dog love best.  You know what that is? A bone. (real close)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can give you a bone, too, girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not my type.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't matter.  I let the monster out, you gonna do what it wants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a minute. Her hand goes into her bag next to the chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring your own rubbers with you? Her hand comes out of the bag holding what looks like the on a golf club.  Kenneth grins at her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else you have in there, mace? Have a whistle, different kinds of female-protection shit? Karen pushes out of the chair to stand with him face-to-f

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to go, Kenneth. She gives him a friendly poke with the black vinyl baton like a golf club grip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we'll see each other again, okay? She steps aside and brushes past him.  He grabs her left

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gonna tussle first. Karen flicks the baton and sixteen inches of chrome steel out of the grip.  She pulls an arm's length away from him chops the rigid shaft at his head, Kenneth hunching, duck away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God damn... He lets go of her and Karen gets the room she needs, so t when he comes at her, she whips the shaft across the side his head and he howls, stops dead, presses a hand over hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanted to tussle, we tussled. And she walks out.  She sees Moselle standing there in th Karen looks at her a moment, puts the baton in her purse comes out with a business card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wrote my hotel number on there -- in case you run into Glenn. Moselle slips the card into the pocket of her robe.  Kare at her and walks out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's snowing pretty hard when Foley and Buddy pull up out

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buddy wipes the condensation off his window, so they can the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that's a really big house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, look at that wall.  Place almost looks like a prison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No doubt the man's got some big-ass security system.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time comes, we knock on the door.  See if he wants to talk about old times. Go in the easy way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?  You think he'll let us in, we got Snoopy and the muscle-bound asshole with us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who says anybody's gonna be with us? I say we go to the fights tomorrow, find out what the Snoop's big plan is, then go in ahead of those guys -- alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let Glenn deal with the Snoop, while we're off livin' the good life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me something, Buddy.  You know anyone who's actually done one last big score and gone to live the good life?  Cause it occurred to me that everyone talks about doing it, but I don't know anyone who's actually gone and done it.  Do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about that D.B. Cooper guy? Foley looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, they don't know for sure he's dead. (then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, there's always a chance we'll walk out've there with nothing.  I say let fate decide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let fate decide?  What're you, the fuckin' Dali Lama now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My sister believes in fate, but not hell.  That's why she stopped praying for the lost souls since you don't hear that much about purgatory anymore. But every day she asks her boss to pray I don't fuck up.  Whatta you think, you think there's a hell, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's called Glades Correctional Institution and I'm sure as shit not going back there or any place like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might not have a choice. Foley looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They put a gun on you, you'll go back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They put a gun on you, you still have a choice, don't you? Foley turns back to the house.  And now we hear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're gonna fit right in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The personnel guy, MR. HEARN, sits behind his desk, squee grip exerciser and smiling warmly at Foley, who wears a s suit and tie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Mr Ripley and I have had a long discussion about your role in the company and it was his feeling that you would be happiest working down here in Miami.  How's that sound to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. Mr. Hearn pauses, looks down at Foley...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're about a 42 long, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? But Mr. Hearn walks out without answering.  Foley looks a desktop, where a spoon sticks out of a half-eaten fruit-o bottom yogurt, which in turn sits beside a half-eaten Pow Foley shakes his head, takes out his zippo, starts to pla it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.  Let's see how she fits. Foley turns as Mr. Hearn bounces back into the room with looks like a UNIFORM draped over one arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My what? Mr. Hearn shows him the yellow patch that reads SECURITY arm.  Foley smiles... amused... angry... hurt...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you kidding me?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD RIPLEY'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: View.  Wet bar.  Huge fucking aquarium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, you can't go in there... Ripley looks up from his desk as Foley steps in, the rece right behind him now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack?  Whoa-- what's the problem? Take it easy, let's talk... Meanwhile, Ripley pushes a PANIC BUTTON beneath his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A security guard?  Are you fucking kidding me? Ripley considers Foley a moment, then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I wasn't sure you'd show up. But I was pretty sure that, if you did, you'd throw the job in my face. (then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Understand something, Jack.  Up to this point, everything you've done with your life means absolutely nothing in the real world.  Less than nothing. Foley says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a bank robber.  This is not a marketable skill.  There are no old bank robbers out in the world living on pensions.  You know this.  That's why you're here right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still Foley says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today, I'm offering you a lousy job at a lousy wage.  You think you're better than that?  Fine.  Show me.  Show me that you're really willing to change and we'll talk about something better. A lot better.  But first, Jack, you gotta earn it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How, Dick?  The way you earned it?  By marrying some rich broad owns the company, selling it off a piece at a time, then divorcing her?  What is this Knute Rockne, pull yourself up by the bootstraps bullshit?  Back in prison, guy like you, place like that, you were ice cream for freaks.  You were a goddamn dumpling.  Maurice and a dozen other guys coulda bled you till you had nothing.  Till you were nothing.  I saved your ass.  So you'll pardon me if I don't wanna sit on a fuckin stool all day saying "sign in here please" or "hey, pal, you can't park there."  Okay, Dick?  I can't do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, I'm disappointed.  I guess I misjudged you. Two massive SECURITY GUARDS appear in the doorway...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, what job he promise you guys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's two ways we can do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?  What are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen.  I think we've calmed down now.  Haven't we, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, I'm calm.  In fact, I'm totally "relaxed..." And with that he picks up a paperweight (A LEAD FISH) and it at the aquarium, shattering the glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Foley is physically thrown out of the building by the guards.  He picks himself up.  He kicks at the guards, wh him off, go back inside. Foley then starts down the steps, pauses as he sees...

dialogues.speaker: THE BANK ACROSS THE STREET
dialogues.text: The one from the opening.  Foley looks at it a moment, th calmly starts to take off his tie, drops it in the gutter starts across the street...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Buddy pulls away from the house, Foley pulls out the c Karen he tore out of the morning paper.  He's written the "WESTIN" on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I gotta get some better shoes, few other things before tomorrow.  Why don't you drop me off at the Ren Cen, we'll hook up later?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, and I better call my sister.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: It's really coming down.  We then PULL BACK TO REVEAL we' looking out of a window inside the cocktail lounge at the the Westin. A table of three young EXECUTIVE-LOOKING GUYS in suits ar laughing at something until Karen is ushered by a WAITRES an adjacent table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack Daniel's, please, water on the side. She turns, sees her reflection in the glass against the o sky, snow swirling, blowing in gusts, seven hundred feet the city, down there somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Celeste, do us again, please, and put the lady's drink on our bill. She turns to see them raising snifter glasses to her, smi pleasant-looking guys in dark suits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drifting over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They want to buy you a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get that.  Tell them I'd rather pay for my own. She then watches the three guys looking at the waitress delivering the message.  Then they look at Karen.  She gi them a shrug, turns to watch the snow.  Her drink arrives takes a sip, looks up as one of the guys comes over...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me.  My associates and I made a bet on what you do for a living. She glances at the table, the other two watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I won.  Hi, I'm Philip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it's okay with you, Philip, I'd like to just have a quiet drink and leave.  Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you want to know what I guessed? How I know what you do for a living?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell you the truth, I'm not even mildly curious.  Really, I don't want to be rude, Philip, I'd just like to be left alone. She turns back to the snowstorm.  She sees his reflection and leave.  A moment later, the next one appears at the t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I know why you're depressed -- if I may offer an observation. She just looks at him.  So sure of himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a hunch you're the new sales rep and your customer isn't exactly knocked out by the idea of a young lady, even one as stunning as you, handling the account.  Am I close? Hi, I'm Andy. She says nothing to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're ad guys.  We flew in from New York this morning to pitch Hiram Walker Distillery, present this test-market campaign for their new margarita mix. What we do, we show this guy who looks like a Mexican bandido, you know, with the big Chihuahua hat, the bullet belts--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy?  Really.  Who gives a shit? He gives her a sympathetic expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want to tell me what happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat it, will you? She stares at the guy until he turns away.  She sips her stares once more out at the blizzard.  After a few moment another dark suit appears, reflected in the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I buy you a drink? Boom.  Not one of the executive guys.  She stares at the reflection for a moment, then slowly turns, looks up at J FOLEY now standing there in his new navy blue suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'd love one. (then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to sit down? He pulls the chair out, looking at her.  The three guys a other table now staring as he sits down.  Foley offers hi hand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Gary. She hesitates, then shakes his hand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Celeste. She smiles with him.  When she lowers her hand to the tab his hand comes down to cover hers.  She watches his expre as she brings her hand out slowly, his eyes not leaving h and lays her hand on his.  The tips of her fingers brush knuckles, lightly back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It takes hours to get a drink around here.  There's only one waitress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can go to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't leave me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those guys bother you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, they're all right.  I meant, you just got here. She picks up her drink and places it in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help yourself. She watches him take a sip, smack his lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like bourbon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (passes the glass back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we got that out of the way. (then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me, Celeste.  What do you do for a living?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a sales rep.  I came here to call on a customer and they gave me a hard time because I'm a girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that how you think of yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, as a sales rep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have a problem with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like your hair.  And that suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had one just like it -- well, it was the same idea, but I had to get rid of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It smelled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Having it cleaned didn't help, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. (then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do for a living, Gary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How far do we go with this? This stops her, throws her off balance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet.  Don't say anything yet.  Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think it works if we're somebody else.  You know what I mean?  Gary and Celeste, Jesus, what do they know about anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your game.  I've never played this before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not a game.  Something you play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, does it make sense to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't have to, it's something that happens.  It's like seeing a person you never saw before -- you could be passing on the street -- you look at each other and for a few seconds, there's a kind of recognition.  Like you both know something.  But then the next moment the person's gone, and it's too late to do anything about it, but you remember it because it was right there and you let it go, and you think, "What if I had stopped and said something?"  It might happen only a few times in your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or once. They look at each other a moment, then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't we get out of here. They both get up.  The ad guys at the table watch as she Foley to the elevator.  Karen winks at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they ride down to Karen's room.  She looks at him, loo away.  The doors open and they exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he follows her in.  She walks to the bar, fixes them e drink.  He checks out the room, takes in her view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you find me? He comes over to her, takes out the newspaper clipping wi picture and shows it to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I called your room from downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I had answered, what were you gonna say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'd say who I was and do you remember me and ask if you'd like to meet for a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I remembered you.  I came looking for you.  I would've said sure, let's do it.  But for all you knew I could show up with a SWAT team.  Why would you trust me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would be worth the risk. She looks at him, touches his face with her hand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like taking risks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So do you. He kisses her now, puts his arms around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the hurry, Jack?  You have to be somewhere? She hands him his drink.  They both drink, then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sooner or later... She stops and he looks at her over the rim of her glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really wear that suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not what you were about to say. She shrugs, lets it go.  He puts down his drink, kisses h She lets him, then moves to the couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember how talkative you were?  In the trunk?  Adele said you do that when you're nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She did, huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You kept touching me, feeling my thigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but in a nice way. He sits down and they kiss again.  This time she peels hi off.  He does the same with hers.  He's starting to unbut her blouse when--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unbuttoning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might've smelled like a sewer, but you could tell I was a gentleman. They say John Dillinger was a pretty nice guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He killed a police officer. He stops.  Looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear he didn't mean to.  The cop fell as Dillinger was aiming at his leg and got him through the heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You believe that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? She looks at him, decides to get off this subject.  Anywa finished unbuttoning her blouse and is now putting his ha inside her shirt.  She closes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know that Sig .380 you took was my favourite.  My father gave it to me. As he kisses her on the neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were you gonna do with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  I hadn't worked that part out yet.  All I knew was that I liked you, and I didn't want to leave you there, never see you again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You waved to me in the elevator. She's loosening his tie, unbuttoning his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't sure you caught that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't believe it.  I was thinking of you by then, a lot, wondering what it would be like if we did meet.  Like if we could take a time-out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?  I was thinking the same thing. If we could call time and get together for a while. They look at each other a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know I saw you on the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside Adele's. He starts to kiss her again, but--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
